The Proper Human Sexual Rights and Ghanaian Family Values bill - or, more simply, the Ghanaian anti-LGBTQ bill - is a piece of Ghanian legislation which aims to introduce restrictions on LGBTQ persons, essentially making it illegal to identify as any sexual orientation other than heterosexual.

According to [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghanaian_anti-LGBTQ_bill#Domestic_reactions), it was introduced in June 2021:

> [Speaker of the Parliament of Ghana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speaker_of_the_Parliament_of_Ghana "Speaker of the Parliament of Ghana") [Alban Bagbin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alban_Bagbin "Alban Bagbin") stated that LGBT+ rights "should not be encouraged or accepted by our society" and that "urgent actions are being taken to pass a law to eventually nip the activities of \[LGBTQ] groups in the bud."

From then on, the bill successfully went through three 'readings', as well as several committee hearings. However, then President, Nana Akufo-Addo, failed to sign the bill into law, latterly refusing to do so until two Supreme Court cases challenging the legislation were concluded.

Upon passing the Presidency to current President John Mahama, the bill expired, but the expiry was short lived, and those sponsoring the bill revived it with a renewed legal basis in light of both Supreme Court cases being [unanimously dismissed](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/crrw2r8epw8o#:~:text=Ghana's%20Supreme%20Court%20has%20unanimously,forming%20or%20funding%20LGBT%20groups.):

> A bill that would make it illegal to be anything but heterosexual in Ghana has been reintroduced in parliament with stronger backing than it got the last time lawmakers tried to get it passed into law.

> \[...]

> A parliamentary committee is expected to start its public hearings on the bill’s contents after it resumes from recess in May, said George, who’s also minister of communications in Ghana’s new cabinet.

**Hong Kong's top court ordered more protections for same-sex couples. Lawmakers said no.**
Hong Kong's Legislative Council rejected a government-sponsored bill in October 2025 that would have granted limited legal recognition to same-sex couples, despite a 2023 ruling by Hong Kong's top court ordering the government to establish an alternative framework for legal recognition—such as civil partnerships—by October 27, 2025. The bill, which aimed to provide rights including hospital visitation, medical record access, and organ donation decisions for same-sex couples, was opposed by 71 out of 86 lawmakers, who cited concerns over 'traditional Chinese values' and a 'lack of social consensus.' The veto marked the first major legislative split with the government since Beijing's 2021 'patriots-only' electoral reform, which eliminated pro-democracy representation. Although the Hong Kong government expressed disappointment, it stated it would respect the legislature’s decision and pursue administrative measures to protect LGBTQ rights, though details remain unclear. This rejection follows a series of progressive court rulings in 2023 and 2024, including the recognition of gender identity changes without surgery, transgender individuals’ right to use public toilets aligned with their affirmed gender, and a lesbian couple’s right to both mothers’ names on their child’s birth certificate. However, LGBTQ activism has declined, with events like Pink Dot moving online without explanation. Jimmy Sham, a leading gay rights activist and former political prisoner, called the veto a 'great pity' but urged authorities to seek consensus. Legal experts, including barrister Azan Marwah, criticized the legislature for abdicating responsibility, arguing that lawmakers should have amended the bill instead of rejecting it outright. Professor John Burns noted the government delayed action until the last moment, proposing a 'minimalist' bill. Experts warn the lack of legal protections could harm Hong Kong’s global competitiveness, particularly among multinational companies that value diversity. Advocates like law student Louis Ng emphasize that lasting change requires sustained dialogue and engagement with opponents. The Constitutional and Mainland Affairs Bureau did not respond to requests for comment.

The controversy has sparked sharp political divisions, with the opposition New Patriotic Party calling the suspension a political witch hunt.
